history.content:
I'm assuming you only have 16A/B for EE knowledge. Unfortunately 16A/B do a very poor job of representing 105, 120, and 130, which are the real EE intro classes. 16A/B basically pick and choose the parts that are of greatest utility to CS, which is really unhelpful for someone like a device physicist.

Every single other EE class is built on top of one of those 3 or is closely allied. If you like 105, you have 113/140/142. If you like 130, you have 134, 143, and some physics classes. If you like 120, you have 123 and 128 (maybe 126 and 127 but those don't really don't use Fourier theory). 120 will greater insight into 140/142 as well, since you'll be working with more complicated frequency behavior. I would wait until you do those 3 before you choose an IC/devices specialization.

Your safest bet would be to take 105, 120, and 130 in the fall. This past semester, 130 was basically an in-detail version of the middle third of 105. In contrast to the answer below, the classes overlap less now, since they don't cover BJTs in 105 anymore but it's like 1/3 of 130. The first third of 130 and the middle third of 105 are basically the exact same.

---------

Plan 2, except switch EE 143 with EE 130.  Plan 2 over 1 because it is generally a good idea to take 105 and 120 early on and together, since 120 will show up in just about every EE class.  105, 120, and 130 will introduce you to just about every field in electrical engineering, and so you will be able to decide with confidence which career path you wish to pursue (and be willing to adjust your plan accordingly) - the 16 series does not give much insight into what any of the fields are actually about (besides linear algebra?). It can be surprising how quickly interests change once you actually have to work on a subject!  Switching 143 with 130 is useful for three reasons; first, 105 spends a month on device physics, so taking 130 basically guarantees you will ace at least 1/3 of the final.  143 spends an even larger portion on device physics, and depending on the professor/year, sometimes the final is >50% device physics!  130 will also give some background knowledge for 134.

    And, as an aside, it appears like you currently have an interest in either device physics or analog circuits- as someone once in the same shoes as you, be wiling to be flexible with the second semester based on what you find more interesting.  If you discover you enjoy device physics for instance, it would be more worthwhile to start taking quantum mechanics -eventually solid state physics- (chem 120A or Physics 137A/B) and EE230B/C over say 143 (fabrication will be learnt through research in that case).  A circuit designer may consider taking a power electronics or special topics course (either 113 or a 290C) in addition to 140.  But if you find that actually you enjoy say DSP or control theory... don't be afraid, go for it! 

------

Thank you for the comprehensive answers, very appreciate it.

However, I cannot take the 105, 130, 120 all together in Fall 2019 because all options of 130 conflict with all options of 120. Hence, the options are 105 and 143 and (120 or 130). Thank you for the explanations toward my question

children.subject:
Anon who commented on student answer here.

Given your situation, I would say 105 and 120 are definitely the most crucial. 130 is kind of niche; it's really too in-depth for anyone who doesn't want to focus in device physics. 

Also, I agree with Rohit in the student answer that 143 isn't really worth taking. That class is too surface-level compared to 130 for a device physicist to justify taking it, but it's goes too much into the nitty-gritty of fabrication for an IC designer. 

For fall 2019, I would recommend physics 137a if you're a hardcore device guy (or 7c if you havent taken it yet). If you're not dead-set on devices/ICs yet, I would recommend a mathy class like EE 126/127 to see if you like EE theory, or maybe EE 137a to get a taste of power systems.

Thank you for the comprehensive answers, very appreciate it.

However, I cannot take the 105, 130, 120 all together in Fall 2019 because all options of 130 conflict with all options of 120. Hence, the options are 105 and 143 and (120 or 130). Thank you for the explanations toward my question

history.content:
I have 2 plans for the next two semesters:

1. Fall 19 : EE 105, EE 143, EE 130 
    Spring 20 : EE 134, EE 140, EE 120

2. Fall 19 : EE 105, EE 143, EE 120
    Spring 20 : EE 134, EE 140, EE 130

Which one is better, based on the time commitments and the correlation of the modules that will be taught ?
history.subject: Which one is better, 1 or 2?
